titulo: Punch, or the London Charivari, Volume 100, March 28, 1891
resumo: "Punch, or the London Charivari, Volume 100, March 28, 1891" by Various is a satirical magazine and a collection of humorous articles and illustrations published during the late 19th century (Victorian era). Renowned for its witty commentary on social, political, and cultural issues, this volume reflects the humor and viewpoints of its time, providing insights into the societal norms and absurdities of the day.  This particular volume of "Punch" contains a variety of skits, poems, and illustrations mocking political figures, societal trends, and everyday occurrences of the Victorian era. It features pieces such as "The G.P.O. Cuckoo," which critiques the Postmaster-General's stance on postal services, and satirical examinations of theatre, parliamentary proceedings, and public figures through humor and outrageous scenarios. The magazine presents a rich tapestry of the social commentaries and comedic delineations characteristic of its genre, capturing the essence of English wit while addressing contemporary issues and events that were pertinent to its readership.
